apple: A round fruit with red, yellow, or green skin and crisp flesh.
banana: A long curved fruit with a yellow skin and soft sweet flesh.
computer: An electronic device for storing and processing data.
dictionary: A book or electronic resource that lists words and their meanings.
elephant: A very large animal with a long trunk and tusks.
flower: The seed-bearing part of a plant.
jungle: An area of land overgrown with dense forest and tangled vegetation.
knowledge: Facts, information, and skills acquired through experience or education.
mountain: A large natural elevation of the earth's surface.
notebook: A book with blank pages for writing notes.
ocean: A very large expanse of sea.
question: A sentence worded to elicit information.
rainbow: An arch of colors visible in the sky.
technology: The application of scientific knowledge for practical purposes.
algorithm: A step-by-step procedure for solving a problem or accomplishing a task.
biology: The study of living organisms and their interactions.
climate: The weather conditions prevailing in an area over a long period.
data: Facts and statistics collected together for reference or analysis.
ecology: The study of how organisms interact with their environment.
festival: A day or period of celebration, typically for religious reasons.
gravity: The force that attracts objects toward one another.
hydrogen: The lightest chemical element, colorless, odorless gas.
innovation: The introduction of new methods, ideas, or products.
journey: An act of traveling from one place to another.
kinetic: Relating to or resulting from motion.
molecule: A group of atoms bonded together.
nutrition: The process of providing or obtaining food necessary for health and growth.
oxygen: A colorless, odorless reactive gas, vital for living organisms.
quantum: The smallest discrete unit of a phenomenon.
robot: A machine capable of carrying out complex tasks automatically.
satellite: An artificial body placed in orbit around the earth or other planet.
telescope: An optical instrument designed to make distant objects appear closer.
universe: All existing matter and space considered as a whole.
vaccine: A substance used to stimulate the production of antibodies for immunity.
website: A location on the World Wide Web containing interconnected webpages.
xenon: A chemical element, a colorless, odorless, inert gas.
yoga: A Hindu spiritual and physical discipline.
zenith: The highest point reached by a celestial object.
acoustic: Relating to sound or the sense of hearing.
bacteria: Microscopic single-celled organisms lacking a nucleus.
calendar: A chart showing the days, weeks, and months of a year.
database: A structured set of data held in a computer.
ecosystem: A biological community of interacting organisms and their environment.
fashion: A popular or the latest style of clothing, hair, decoration, or behavior.
genome: The complete set of genes or genetic material in an organism.
horizon: The line at which the earth's surface and the sky appear to meet.
insulin: A hormone produced in the pancreas regulating glucose levels.
jazz: A type of music characterized by improvisation and syncopation.
kangaroo: A large marsupial native to Australia.
library: A building containing collections of books for reading or borrowing.
microscope: An instrument used to view objects too small for the naked eye.
nostalgic: Feeling or inspiring a wistful affection for the past.
orbit: The curved path of an object around a star, planet, or moon.
polymer: A substance with a molecular structure built up from similar units.
quantum: The smallest discrete unit of a phenomenon.
resonance: The quality of being deep, full, and reverberating.
symphony: An elaborate musical composition for full orchestra.
tornado: A violent rotating column of air extending from a thunderstorm to the ground.
utopia: An imagined place or state of things in which everything is perfect.
volcano: A mountain or hill with a crater through which lava, rock, and gas erupt.
wilderness: An uncultivated, uninhabited, and inhospitable region.
xylophone: A musical instrument played by striking wooden bars with mallets.
yearn: To have an intense feeling of longing for something.
zodiac: A belt of the heavens divided into twelve equal parts named after constellations.
autumn: The season between summer and winter, also called fall.
blueprint: A design plan or technical drawing.
coral: A hard, stony substance secreted by certain marine polyps.
democracy: A form of government in which the people have the authority to deliberate and decide legislation.
equation: A statement that the values of two mathematical expressions are equal.
frequency: The rate at which something occurs over a particular period of time.
galaxy: A system of millions or billions of stars, together with gas and dust.
heritage: Features belonging to the culture of a particular society.
illusion: A false perception or belief; a deceptive appearance or impression.
justice: The quality of being fair and reasonable.
kilowatt: A unit of power equal to one thousand watts.
latitude: The angular distance of a place north or south of the earth's equator.
metaphor: A figure of speech in which a word is applied to an object to which it is not literally applicable.
nucleus: The central and most important part of an object or group.
oscillate: Move or swing back and forth in a regular rhythm.
paradigm: A typical example or pattern of something; a model.
quotient: A result obtained by dividing one quantity by another.
rhetoric: The art of effective or persuasive speaking or writing.
synthesis: The combination of components to form a connected whole.
theorem: A general proposition not self-evident but proved by reasoning.
velocity: The speed of something in a given direction.
wavelength: The distance between successive crests of a wave.
xenophobia: Dislike of or prejudice against people from other countries.
yield: Produce or provide a natural, agricultural, or industrial product.
